oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Canaan Baptist Church: education annex cornerstone
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 824 Fifteenth St North, Bessemer, Jefferson County, AL

Color photograph of the cornerstone of the 1984 education building for Canaan Baptist Church. Text inscribed in stone reads: "Education Building. July 29, 1984. Deacons and Trustees. Bro. Robert Marshall, Chrm., Earl Dowdley, Chrm. Emeritus DEA. Board. Robert Fikes, chrm. Bro. Johnyy Akers, Jr., George Alexander, Charlie Harris, William Hunter, Pride Jones, Lot Lewis, H.B. Moore, Rev. Raymond Coats, Bro. Edward Robinson, William B. Smith, Sr., Otis Studimire, Larry townsend Sr., Joseph Terrell, Jr. Ishmeal Taylor, Sis. Odessa Johnson, Willie Lee Lewis. Rev. H.P. Turner, Pastor. To God be the glory."

Canaan Baptist Church is locally significant because of its association as a key Bessemer strategy center during the Civil Rights Movement in Birmingham during the early 1960s. Established in 1865 by Reverend W.M. Grimes, Canaan Baptist is the oldest African American Baptist congregation in Bessemer. The present church building was constructed in 1961. The civil rights associations lie largely with the leadership of Rev. Dr. J.H. Browder, who was pastor of Canaan Baptist from 1948 until his death in 1964. He and other members were active in Christian Aid Union and Alabama Christian Movement for Human Rights in the late 1950s.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African American Churches -- Tennessee
